Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Does Na availability regulate tropical decomposers?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Much of Earth's carbon cycle can be described briefly thus: plants scrub carbon dioxide from the atmosphere; animals, fungi, and bacteria consume plants and release carbon dioxide back into the atmosphere. This proposal posits that sodium (the Na in NaCl, or table salt) plays a key, under-appreciated role in regulating atmospheric carbon dioxide. Most plants don't need sodium, but decomposer animals and fungi do (and suffer in low-sodium ecosystems like a sports team deprived of Gatorade). Low-sodium ecosystems should thus tend to store carbon. Ecosystems farther inland receive less and less ocean source sodium in their rainfall. Decomposers of earth's vast continental interior should thus be especially sodium deprived, less active, and less likely to release carbon back into the atmosphere. We will test this hypothesis in two ways. First, for three months, 5 x 5 m patches in an Ecuador forest 2500 km inland will receive one of two treatments. Half will be regularly watered from a nearby river. The other half will get river water charged with NaCl (about the amount found in a year's worth of coastal rainfall). This experiment will test if more of a forest's leaf and woody litter decomposes with added sodium. Second, small-scale experiments will compare how ecosystem responses vary geographically between two forests: one, our site in Ecuador, the other in Panama, only 25 km from the ocean. A common sodium supplement-urine-will be the experimental focus. Four treatments--synthetic urine, urine sans NaCl, NaCl, and water--will be added to small patches of forest for three weeks. If the above hypothesis is true, the NaCl component of urine should increase decomposition more in the Ecuador forest. Both experiments will monitor sodium effects up the food web on decomposer arthropods and their predators, which comprise about half the biodiversity in a tropical forest.

Most of Earth's terrestrial ecosystems are far enough from the ocean to experience sodium limitation. The work funded by this proposal thus has the potential to significantly increase understanding of the Earth's climate system. If the amount and distribution of rainfall changes with global warming, as predicted by current models, this may mean changes in sodium deposition, which in turn could increase or decrease atmospheric carbon dioxide. The biodiversity part of this study will collect thousands of specimens (and, almost certainly, species not yet described) in this poorly understood part of the world. A graduate student will be trained in a multidisciplinary endeavor linking earth science, evolutionary biology, and ecosystem ecology. She in turn will mentor an undergraduate from the University of Oklahoma, who will join us in the field and experience biodiversity science first hand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are 25 or so chemical elements required for life. This means that any given organism requires the appropriate concentration of those elements or risk disease or death. Since the world's ecosystems are made up of organisms, it stands to reason that ecosystems only function when those 25 elements are available. 

One of the great challenges for modern ecology is to understand how carbon cycles from the CO2 of our atmosphere to the various organic forms found in living and dead organisms. This is especially important nowadays, as a lot of the carbon from once dead trees and dinosaurs is being unearthed, burned, and transferred into the atmosphere, warming the planet. Understanding the precise way that plants scrub the atmosphere of this CO2, and feeding all the animal and microbial consumers, and how all of life burns through this carbon, will give us a better handle on how much more CO2 is likely to accumulate, and how much warmer the planet will become. 

Understanding the role of chemical elements in this process is typically pretty difficult, as both plants (that capture CO2) and the rest of life (including plants, which chemically "burn" the stored carbon from plant tissue) need them and use them in subtlely different ways. 

Not so sodium (Na), one of two elements in table salt. Due to a fluke of evolutionary history, plants don't use sodium, and high concentrations are toxic to most plants. In contrast, everything that eats plants requires it. One consequence, we reasoned, is that only one half of the carbon cycle--the part that breaks down wood, and leaves, the stored CO2 in plants, and is performed by animals and microbes, is likely to be hindered by a lack of sodium.  If true, this means that low sodium environments, by slowing down the conversion of plant tissue to CO2, would tend to store carbon outside of the atmosphere, and keep the planet cooler. 

Where do we find low sodium environments?  The short answer is: far from the ocean. Sodium is deposited in rainwater, and the churning oceans pump a lot of sodium into the atmosphere. However, it mostly falls close to shore, so that, as you move further from the ocean, rainwater becomes less and less like dilute seawater, and more and more like the distilled water you pour into your irons. 

In our experiment we added water that we mixed up to mimic the salty rainwater of Puerto Rico to a tropical forest floor 2000 kilometers inland, in the Amazon rainforests of Ecuador. We compared the rate that a variety of plant-based products, paper, and wood, decomposed when getting the oh-so salty water to regular river water. We found, over the course of a year, that all those plant products decomposed--converting wood to CO2--up to 75% faster in the salty plots. Moreover, the things that do the decomposing were also more common.

Why is this important?  Most of our landarea, 90%, is at least 100 km from an ocean, most of it much more. Our results suggest that the balance of decomposition to plant production may be subtly biased against decomposition, preserving carbon in the soil, because inland organisms are sodium deprived (in the same way that a football team in the fourth quarter would slow down without their sports drinks).  In other words, holding everything else equal (like precipitation and temperature), inland ecosystems should, if we are correct, store carbon better for their lack of sodium. 

It also suggest other ways that humans may enhance CO2 in the atmosphere and thus promote warming. One is through the use of salt to de-ice roads in the winter. The other is through the increasing frequency and severity of tropical storms, which can import sodium from oceans far inland.
